ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

DENGUE CONTROL MEASURES

     1.  Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan asked the Minister for the Environment and Water Resources (a) if he can provide (i) an update on the number of reported dengue cases over the last six weeks; and (ii) the number of fatalities due to dengue fever for this year; (b) what new measures the Ministry is planning to implement to combat dengue fever; and (c) how the Ministry co-ordinates with other Ministries and relevant agencies like the Ministry of Health, Land Transport Authority and National Parks Board to ensure an efficient, speedy and effective response to public feedback on potential breeding grounds.   

 

 

     The Minister for the Environment and Water Resources (Assoc. Prof. Dr Yaacob Ibrahim):  Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, with the indulgence of the House, I will make a statement later.

 

     Mr Deputy Speaker:  OK.

Column: 1299

PUBLIC AND PRIVATE SECTOR APARTMENTS

(Replacement of window rivets)

     2.   Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan asked the Minister for National Development (a) whether he can provide an update on the latest known number of public and private sector apartments that are required to, but have yet to get the rivets of their windows replaced; (b) what measures the Ministry has taken or will take to ensure that the owners of these apartments comply with the requirement by the deadline set; and (c) what are the implications for flat owners if they are unable to comply by the deadline.

     3.  Dr Lily Neo asked the Minister for National Development if he will consider postponing the 30th September 2005 cut-off date for retrofitting windows in view of the fact that many owners of HDB and private apartments may have difficulty in meeting this deadline.

 

 

     The Minister for National Development (Mr Mah Bow Tan):  Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, may I have your permission to take Question Nos. 2 and 3 together as they are related?

     Mr Deputy Speaker:   Yes.

 

     Mr Mah Bow Tan:  Sir, first of all, let me explain why we carried out the window retrofitting exercise.  Last year, the incidence of falling windows rose sharply, from 107 cases in 2003 to 133 cases in 2004.  They were mainly caused by corroded aluminium rivets in casement windows.  In a high-rise built-up environment like ours, falling windows pose a serious danger to the life and limb of our residents.  To address this, we required all casement windows fitted with aluminium rivets to be replaced with stainless steel rivets.  In view of the large number of windows involved, we gave a one-year grace period. 

 

Column: 1300

     In the last one year, BCA and HDB embarked on a major campaign to raise public awareness on the need to retrofit their windows.  This was done through direct mail to HDB residents and to management corporations of private estates, press releases, newspaper and radio advertorials, constituency exhibitions and other forums. BCA and HDB trained additional window contractors and linked them up with home-owners.  Town Councils and Management Corporations were also roped in to help coordinate the window retrofitting exercise in their estates.

 

     The response from residents has been encouraging.  To date, the vast majority, or about 94%, of households required to retrofit their windows have already done so.  Dr Lily Neo asked whether the deadline for retrofitting would be extended when it expires on 30th September this year.  My Ministry will not be extending the deadline.  It is not in the interest of public safety to do so.  The grace period of one year has been more than adequate.  The vast majority has had no problem complying.  The small minority who has not yet done so will be given additional help to do so.  Dr Amy Khor asked for a breakdown of these residents.  To-date, about 12,000 units have not yet fixed their windows. Of these, 4,000 are HDB units and 8,000 are private units.  They constitute about 3% of 150,000 HDB flats with casement windows that need to be retrofitted and about 20% of private flats.

 

     Dr Khor also asked what additional measures would be taken to help those who have not retrofitted their windows.  HDB and BCA have increased the number of hotlines that home-owners can call to seek assistance, and deployed more staff to tend to queries.  They have also appointed more window contractors to meet the increase in demand.  Home-owners who need assistance can call the HDB or BCA hotline for help.

 

Column: 1301

     BCA and HDB have also taken stern actions against errant contractors who tried to take advantage of the current situation. Errant contractors who are found to be involved in malpractices like over-charging, providing misleading information or rendering poor service, would be fined or debarred from HDB contracting works.  So far, HDB has taken action against 49 contractors.

 

     Dr Khor asked about the implications for flat owners who are unable to retrofit their window rivets by the deadline.  With the stepped up efforts by HDB and BCA, I expect that virtually all home-owners will be able to meet the deadline.  Those who still have problems retrofitting their windows should contact HDB or BCA for advice and assistance immediately.  After the deadline, BCA will take action under the window retrofitting order against home-owners who do not have valid reasons for not fixing their affected windows.

 

     May I remind all flat-owners that this exercise is to save lives. With the cooperation of everyone, I hope we will be able to make our housing estates safe for our families, our friends and ourselves.

 

     Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan (Hong Kah):  Sir, I would like to ask the Minister, since the deadline is barely two weeks away, what would the valid reasons be for home-owners who do not retrofit their windows by the deadline.  Would financial difficulties be one of the valid reasons? 

 

     I would also like, in this regard, to ask the Minister how many home-owners have approached HDB for help regarding the retrofitting of their windows due to financial difficulties.  What help or advice has the HDB given to these residents?  Has any home-owner been assisted by the HDB and allowed to pay the retrofitting cost, say, by instalments as the Minister had, during the Committee of Supply

Column: 1302

debate last year, said that home-owners in financial difficulties could approach the HDB Branch Office for assistance and some consideration could be made to allow them to pay by instalments?

     Mr Mah Bow Tan:  Sir, the number of residents who have approached HDB for financial assistance directly is not significant.  There are a few cases which have come to the HDB directly, others have come to the MPs.  In my own meet-the-people session, I have several cases also.  In all these cases where the HDB assesses there is genuine financial difficulty, HDB will  direct them to the relevant community organisation. Where such assistance is not available, it will also be prepared to do the retrofitting exercise and collect the payment on an instalment basis.  It has also come to my notice that some contractors have, for the very poor cases, been carrying out this retrofitting exercise either on a complimentary basis or on an instalment basis.  So there are several avenues available for such financial cases to be assisted.  But I must stress that these are, by and large, in a minority.  I think the number of cases that have come to our attention has not been significant. Where they have genuine difficulties, they have been given assistance of one form or another.  I do not think this is the main issue.

     Dr Lily Neo (Jalan Besar):   Sir, may I ask the Minister how he intends to enforce this ruling on the change of window rivets?  Is he going to have random checks on private apartments and HDB flats?  Would he be lenient to those with good reasons for not being able to meet the target deadline?

 

     May I also ask the Minister how is he addressing the complaints about some HDB-recommended contractors who over-

Column: 1303

service beyond requirements, some who overcharge, and some disappear after collecting the deposits?  How many of such complaints has his Ministry received?

 

     Mr Mah Bow Tan:  There have been complaints about errant contractors and they are the culprits who either overcharge or run away with the money.  Each and every complaint is investigated and, so far, HDB has taken action against 49 contractors.  However, a lot of the complaints have been found to be due to misunderstanding on the part of the contractors as well as the home-owners.  For example, some of the contractors, having inspected the windows, found that the windows needed repairs other than changing of the rivets.  In those cases, they recommended additional works to be done and of course these additional works cost money.  Because there was a misunderstanding as to what needed to be done, home-owners may have thought  that they were being overcharged.  All those misunderstandings have been clarified to the satisfaction of both parties.  So I do not think we need to worry about that.  But I do admit that there are contractors who have tried to take advantage of the situation.

     I also know of contractors, through their own volition, who have given either free service or allowed instalment payments.   Where there are cases of contractors taking advantage of the situation and where we can prove it, we will either fine them or debar them from the contractors registry system under HDB.  If there are any complaints of this nature, residents can always call up the hotline and they will be investigated.

     The first question pertains to enforcement.  BCA can either enforce it through the window retrofitting order or the Building Maintenance Act.  But that is

Column: 1304

not the point.  The more serious point is that we want everybody to have a sense of urgency to change or check their windows and to make sure they do not fall down.  It is not possible for BCA to go round checking every single house which has not complied.  If they want to do it at the end of the period, they will reserve the option to do so.  But what is more serious, and this is where I would like to urge all home-owners to be aware, is that when a window falls down after that date, they can be subject to severe penalties.  Although there were one or two cases in the past where the windows had fallen down, after investigations, BCA and HDB had not taken action against the owners.  But after 30th September, if such an incident happens, depending on the investigations, home-owners may be subject to far more severe penalties.

     My advice is, first of all, get your windows fixed and, even after that, check your windows regularly. If there is anything that is not quite right, please approach either a window contractor, the HDB or management corporation, for assistance.

     Mdm Cynthia Phua (Aljunied):  Sir, I just want to clarify with the Minister whether the 4,000 home-owners who have not retrofitted their windows are from the list of HDB known cases, ie, HDB's subsidised cases.  I will give him an example.  Aljunied Town Council has been monitoring the cases and it has also been helping the residents.  In total, Aljunied Town Council has actually helped 9,000 cases to change their windows.  This is on top of the 4,300 HDB cases that have been done by the Hougang Branch Office.  The number of cases that have not changed their window rivets, which need to be changed, may not be the number that the Minister has stated so. 

 

    In addition, because of a complaint, I have actually gone down to visit two

Column: 1305

blocks of flats.  There are two categories of residents:  one is those who are in financial difficulty and the other category is those who do not know how to call the agency.  There are about 10 to 20 of these cases in each block.  How is the Minister going to help these cases?

     Mr Mah Bow Tan:  I think the Member is doing a very good job in going round to help the residents.  I am quite assured that I do not have to do anything much.  Having said that, if there is any help that is needed over and above what she is doing, she can always approach the HDB Branch Office and they will render every assistance possible.   Those in financial difficulties, we will find a way to help them.  But the difficulty is in determining what constitute genuine financial difficulties.  If they stay in a 5-room flat and they have a 52-inch plasma TV in the living room, I do not think we are going to help them.  But we will look at it on a case-by-case basis.

 

     As for the numbers, there are two categories.  The first category would be those under the goodwill repair scheme.  These were the ones where the windows were originally fitted by HDB, and  based on HDB's records, have not been changed since then.  Under the goodwill repair scheme, HDB will co-pay part of the cost and


will arrange for the retrofitting to be done. The other category will be those who have changed their original windows when they renovated their flats.

 

      For both these cases, HDB will be monitoring the numbers.  In the first instance, for the goodwill repair scheme, I think there are slightly more than a thousand cases left, and HDB has assured me that they will be able to complete it before 30th September.  The other cases are the cases including those mentioned by the Member for Aljunied.  For these cases, we will have to take special steps to try and get them to retrofit before the deadline.

Column: 1306

      One of the common complaints is that the contractors are all busy and, therefore, they cannot meet the deadline.  There are over 600 contractors registered by BCA.  There are another 24 which are term contractors specifically designated by HDB.  There are other term contractors which have been appointed by Town Councils.  The total capacity of all these contractors is more than 20,000 windows a month.  This is more than adequate to meet the demand of those who have not yet submitted their requests for retrofitting.  It is only those who are either not aware or those who have real financial difficulties.  I think these are the cases that are left and for them, as I said, HDB is prepared to work with the Town Councils to identify cases and to see what assistance can be rendered to them, including advising them on what needs to be done.

     Mr Deputy Speaker: Mdm Khor, one last question from you?

     Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan:  Sir, whilst the number of cases that may need financial assistance may not be very big, but in order to make a one-off financial assistance package more transparent to the residents, could the Ministry consider having some means test or income qualifying criteria, say, $1,500 or $450 per capita, and then get a contractor to undertake the retrofitting and allow them to pay by instalments?  It is something akin to the LUP scheme where we have actually given financial assistance for needy residents.  This will make it more transparent and a lot easier for the different constituencies to deal with residents who need financial assistance.

 

     The other question that I would like to ask the Minister is with regard to people who are not able to get contractors to retrofit the windows by the deadline.  Could the Ministry coordinate and release names of contractors who are able to

Column: 1307

render the service and meet the deadline, because the feedback from residents is that they have made umpteen calls to many contractors and most, if not all, actually said that they could not meet the deadline and can only do it after September?

     Mr Mah Bow Tan:  Sir, I will look into the Member's suggestion about the financial assistance scheme, but please rest assured that those who need financial help will be able to find them somehow or other, including from the branch office.


      As regards residents not being able to get contractors to meet the deadline, I have indicated that there is a list of 600 contractors.  If Members look at the HDB's website, they will be able to see that each zone has easily got 20-30 or more contractors whose order books are still not full and who are able to take new jobs.  It is only a matter of taking the trouble to look for them.  But even after all this, if they still have difficulty, they can call up the HDB hotline.  Or if they go to the Town Council office, they have got a whole list of other names that they can call.  So it is not a matter of contractors not being available.  It is a matter of trying.  I think this is really something that we need to instil in our residents as well  -  a sense of urgency.

 

     This accident is something that can happen.  We do not want it to happen, but it can happen and it can happen to any household.  And if it does happen, the consequences can be very serious.  We are very fortunate that so far nobody has been seriously hurt or even killed.  But imagine a full window falling down from 10-20 storeys and hitting somebody.  For us to quibble about not getting contractors without making the effort, I think it does not do justice to the serious consequences of such a thing happening.  So I would urge everybody to please make the effort.  If they are really not able to

Column: 1308

pay, we will find a way to help them.  And for those who really do not know what is happening, there are enough people on the ground going around who are able to help them and provide information to them.

 

      So I think there is no excuse - other than for these two groups - for anybody to say that there are not enough contractors around or that they are not able to do it on time.  We have given them 12 months.  For the last 11 months, all the contractors have been doing work on a steady basis, and most home-owners have complied.  So for the rest who still have not done it, please make the effort.

Column: 1308

Column: 1409

their ability to earn more. These could be, amongst others, some of the disabled and educationally sub-normal who, even if they can find work, cannot earn enough for a decent living.  Secondly, those with psychiatric problems and have been past patients of the IMH and who have extreme difficulty finding work, as well as, thirdly, single parents and families where it is not possible for both parents to work for various genuine reasons, like inability to find affordable and appropriate childcare, and so on.  There are compelling reasons for such groups to receive longer term welfare as it could take some time, if at all possible, before they can become self-reliant.

 

      Currently, social assistance schemes provided under ComCare are available generally on a short-term basis and reviewed every three months, as my colleague, Mr Sin Boon Ann, has noted earlier.  However, the circumstances of the foregoing groups of people are unlikely to change after three months or, for that matter, three years.  Consequently, longer term financial assistance would be more relevant for them.

       Hence, the assistance schemes offered under workfare should be carefully

Column: 1410

considered and packaged to synergise and/or dovetail with the help provided under the ComCare to avoid confusion and waste.  We would also need to allow for some flexibility in the implementation of these workfare schemes.

      Additionally, the residents in the constituency could assist in identifying and alerting, say, the relevant grassroots and/or CDC of anyone who is in need in the community.  Appropriate and timely help could then be provided to the residents.

 

      This morning, I read with a heavy heart the case of an elderly couple who have apparently made their home in a multi-storey carpark in Woodlands for the last six months as reported in the press, Today. 

 

       Their reasons for doing so are, I think, still under investigation.  Nonetheless, this reinforces the continuous need to raise the awareness of the general public and enlist their cooperation to inform the relevant CDC or grassroots of such cases as soon as they are detected so that timely help can be dispatched.  Though such unfortunate cases are, thankfully, quite infrequent, we do read of them from time to time in the press.

Column: 1411

Development that would serve as broad guidelines to implement a comprehensive R&D strategy for Singapore.  I would, however, like this House to consider certain points in transforming these thrusts from concept to reality.

 

Thrust 1: Provide more resources for R&D in Singapore

     (2)  New incentive schemes to promote a higher level of private-sector R&D spending; and

 

     (3)  New mechanisms to enhance technology transfer from research institutes (RIs) and educational institutes to the industry.

Column: 1437

performance in the knowledge-based economy is not measured simply by outputs of science and technology, but must also be judged in relation to the important goal of increasing competitiveness.  Thus, we need to formulate a set of KPIs that is based on our unique characteristics.

Column: 1438

3% GDP within the next five years competitive?

Column: 1439

     Have students been influenced into thinking that life-science holds the key to the future and taking up life-science as their future choice of study?  A more important concern is whether this has reduced the crop, in particular good students, in taking up studies in engineering and physical sciences.  To pursue research in environmental and water technologies and interactive and digital media, a good spread of students in the physical sciences and engineering, rather than just the life-science, is needed.

Thrust 3:  Provide a balance of investigator-led and mission-oriented research in strategic areas

     Sir, we need to develop our own talents in addition to bringing in foreign talents to supplement our R&D manpower.  In Singapore, R&D careers lack attractiveness.  The current low R&D intensity in Singapore results in few R&D positions, out-of-field employment, and possible emigration resulting in a brain drain.  Making research careers more attractive is necessary to increase the inflow of science and engineering educated people into research positions to provide the R&D manpower that we need to move towards an R&D-driven economy.  Increasing R&D positions in Singapore and providing a job-matching service for the PhD holders are two other methods to solve this problem.

     (1)  The university research scholarship monthly allowance of $1,500 is not attractive to local students.  This monthly allowance, however, is attractive to foreign students from the lower-income countries.  To these foreign students, pursuing a higher degree in Singapore is almost like a paid "job", with the reward of a degree after the completion of the job.

of a flat to start a family after marriage; and

Thrust 4:  Encourage even more private sector R&D

Column: 1445

     To encourage more private sector R&D investments, we need to increase the efficiency with which new ideas are turned into new products, processes, services and solutions and improve the protection for intellectual property, so as to create a conducive environment for firms to increase R&D investment in Singapore.

MNCs are less interested in these IPs and technologies created by the universities

and RIs as they already have them from their headquarters and research laboratories.  Thus, there is a need to ensure that the IPs, technologies and research developed by the universities and the RIs are relevant to these MNCs, local large companies and SMEs.

     18.   Prof. Ivan Png Paak Liang asked the Minister for Information, Communications and the Arts if he will consider protecting Singapore consumers from unsolicited telemarketing calls, especially to their mobile numbers when they are roaming overseas, through either regulation, appropriate technology or both.

     

Column: 1457

Dr Lee Boon Yang:

     Prof Png asked about protecting Singapore consumer from unsolicited telemarketing calls.  In a free market economy, we must expect businesses to become more creative in their efforts to win customers.  MICA recognises that telemarketing is a common and bona fide marketing tool used by companies in many countries, but also acknowledges that irresponsible telemarketers are a nuisance to consumers.

 

     Telemarketing involves one-to-one voice communication, which falls in the realm of private communication.  As such, it is difficult to regulate this form of communication.  Indeed, it may cause alarm among the public, if the Government were to monitor such private communication.  For this reason, MDA and IDA do not regulate the content and mode of personal communications over the telephone.  A balance must therefore be sought between curbing irresponsible telemarketing and the Government's intrusion into the area of free communication and privacy.  Instead of direct intervention, there are a number of other safeguards to protect the consumers.

 

     Under the Telecom Competition Code, IDA prohibits telecom licensees from providing their subscribers' information to any third party for marketing any goods and services.  However, telemarketers may not be telecom licensees, and may have solicited, through legal channels, the users' telephone numbers, which means they may not be covered by the Telecom Competition Code.


     Hence, industry-led initiatives are important means to address consumers' concerns.  For example, the Mobile Marketing Council of Singapore (MMCS) was founded in January 2003, under the auspices of the Direct Marketing Association of Singapore (DMAS).  It includes representatives from various segments of the mobile marketing industry, such as advertisers, mobile operators, mobile services providers, and mobile technologies providers.  Its goals include sharing best practices and advising on legal compliance.  In 2004, in response to growing concerns by mobile subscribers, it set out to draw up a position paper on mobile subscribers' privacy.  MMCS is currently working with DMAS on a set of guidelines for responsible mobile and e-mail marketing.

 

     Just last month on 25th August 2005, the Contact Centre Association of Singapore (CCAS) partnered with the Association of Banks in Singapore (ABS) and the Insurance and Financial Practitioners Association of Singapore (IFPAS) to release a set of telemarketing guidelines for the finance industry.  These guidelines establish a common understanding of acceptable conduct when telemarketing financial products.

 

     MICA welcomes further initiatives by industry associations to promote best practices in telemarketing and other forms of direct marketing.

 

     Lastly, there are simple measures that each one of us can adopt to prevent or reduce unsolicited calls to the mobile numbers.  For example, consumers can use the caller-ID function to screen local calls.  Consumers can also buy mobile phones with a built-in function to reject or alert any calls from unknown numbers.  These mobile phones are commonly available from several manufacturers.  However this may not work when a subscriber is roaming overseas, as the call is re-routed and the availability of caller-ID is dependent on the commercially negotiated terms between the operators in the two countries.

 

Column: 1459

     To sum up, in an increasingly connected world, telemarketers must adopt ethical practices. We will continue to engage the DMAS and MMCS to promote responsible mobile marketing through industry guidelines and best practices.  Meanwhile consumers should also exercise care when disclosing their contact information so as to prevent or reduce unsolicited calls from telemarketers.

     8.   Mr Sin Boon Ann asked the Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports whether the Government will now consider an official policy on the use of guide dogs for the blind in public places.

     In the area of environmental health, the Environmental Public Health (Food Hygiene) Regulations currently prohibit live animals or birds in licensed food retail outlets.  This is also the case in various other countries for public hygiene reasons.  However, some countries have exempted guide dogs from their regulations.   The rationale for such an exemption is that being well trained, guide dogs are not likely to compromise environmental hygiene practices, so long as they are harnessed and kept at the owner's side at all times.  The National Environment Agency has recently carried out a review, and has decided to grant licensees of food establishments the discretion to allow guide dogs in their premises, so long as the dogs are harnessed and kept at the owner's side at all times.  This will come into effect before the end of the year.
